thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: BG Group starts production at second LNG train in Gladstone
thread.title_full: BG Group starts production at second LNG train in Gladstone

title: BG Group starts production at second LNG train in Gladstone
text:
Revenues from the plant are set to be lower in the initial phase than might have been expected 12 months ago.
BG Group has begun production at its second LNG production unit at its Queensland LNG export project, marking another milestone at the $US20.4 billion ($27.5 billion) project and putting it on track to reach full production in mid-2016.
The start-up of the second train at BG's Queensland Curtis project will be followed later this year by the beginning of production from the first trains of both Santos's GLNG venture and Origin Energy's Australia Pacific venture.
While the start-up marks a major step forward for Queensland's new $70 billion gas export industry, the new wave of LNG supply is set to hit the Asian market in a period of low prices because of slower than expected growth in demand and weak crude oil prices.
As a result, revenues from the plant are set to be lower in the initial phase than might have been expected 12 months ago when prices were much higher.
Advertisement Ownership of the QCLNG venture is set to pass to Royal Dutch Shell next year should the oil giant's proposed $US70 billion takeover bid for UK-based BG be completed. The bid is still being examined by regulators, including the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, which has asked interested parties to comment on whether supply competition may be affected by the amalgamation of Shell's and BG's interests in Queensland, including its 50 per cent interest in Arrow Energy.
Once the QCLNG venture reaches full capacity, 10 LNG tankers a month will be loading at BG's Gladstone project, exporting about 8 million tonnes a year. Since production from the first LNG train started in late December, 27 cargoes have been shipped.
"We have already shipped more than 1.5 million tonnes of LNG from Queensland and train 2 will add significant further volumes and flexibility to our LNG shipping and marketing portfolio," BG global chief executive Helge Lund said in a statement on Monday.
Much of the LNG from the first train at QCLNG is being shipped to BG's biggest customer for the project, Chinese oil major CNOOC. However CNOOC doesn't have a stake in the second train, which will supplement BG's global portfolio of LNG supplies.
The ACCC is set to announce a decision on the Shell-BG merger on September 3.
